result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

1:15 PM Defendant Nicholas Halsey appeared by video, in custody, Attorney Maxwell Bergner for Nicholas Halsey appeared in court, Attorney Andrew Mutchler for State of Wisconsin appeared in court. 

ADA Mutchler states facts for anticipated charges of Disorderly Conduct/Domestic Abuse, Criminal Trespass to Dwelling and other more serious charges. 
Atty Bergner does not have anything to state about the facts of the case.  Defendant is not eligible for public defender representation at this time. 
Court finds probable cause that a crime has been committed and that this defendant committed it.

State requests a $1,500 cash bond with conditions as stated. 
Atty Bergner makes bond arguments and requests a signature bond. 
Victim is present and makes a statement to the court.
Hearing scheduled for April 18, 2022 at 01:45 pm.
